The following types of files can be played under  (Video).
Memory Stick Video Format
- MPEG-4 SP (AAC LC)
- H.264/MPEG-4 AVC High Profile （AAC LC）
- MPEG-2 TS（H.264/MPEG-4 AVC, AAC LC）
MP4 file format

MPEG-1 (MPEG Audio Layer 2)
MPEG-2 PS (MPEG2 Audio Layer 2, AAC LC, AC3(Dolby Digital), LPCM)
MPEG-2 TS（MPEG2 Audio Layer 2, AC3（Dolby Digital）, AAC LC）
MPEG-2 TS（H.264/MPEG-4 AVC, AAC LC）
AVI
- Motion JPEG (Linear PCM)
- Motion JPEG (μ-Law)
AVCHD （.m2ts / .mts）
DivX
WMV

"What's with all the mp4 files I've been seeing lately? .avi will play on anything (including PS3), but mp4 won't"

First off, it's not the filename, it's the codec used. Just to be nitpicky.

"mp4" files are generally encoded using x264 (H.264/MPEG-4 Part 10 Advanced Video Coding) in use since around 2004, but noticeably only since 2008 and later, with not many consumer-grade equipment supporting it natively yet

"avi" files are lately generally encoded using Xvid (MPEG-4 Part 2 Advanced Simple Profile), in use since 2001 or so, and a hardcoded part of many consumer electronics

Classic commercial DVDs use MPEG2, which is recognized natively by pretty much everything on the market today.


x264 allows better compression rates compared to Xvid (and far, far more compared to MPEG2), so either higher quality or higher resolutions (or a combination thereof) given the same file size, but is significantly more computationally intensive compared to Xvid to decode (which in turn is also noticeably more computationally intensive compared to MPEG2).

Funny enough, PS3 *does* support x264 decoding, but only a very small subset of it, namely high profile, level 4.1 (and nothing else).
You can always just re-encode the movie locally on your computer (using something like the free software Handbrake) so it will be in that particular format.
